questions: Q. 1. Name the monomers which are linked by (i) peptide bond, (ii) glycosidic bond to make their polymers.
answers: Ans. (i) Peptide bond-Amino acids (ii) Glycosidic bond-Monosaccharide units

questions: Q. 2. Name the smallest amino acid and draw its structure.
answers: Ans. Smallest amine acid is glycine.

questions: Q. 3. How many types of amino acids are found to occur in proteins? 2017]  [KVS Agra
answers: Ans. 20

questions: Q. 4. What is Glycosidic bond?
answers: Ans. Glycosidic Bond: It is a bond formed during the condensation of monosaccharides for the formation of oligosaccharides and polysaccharides. ùê∏. ùëî., Cellulose.

questions: Q. 5. Which is the common sugar found in animals?
answers: Ans. Glucose is the common sugar found in animals.

questions: Q. 6. What is the other name given to carbohydrates?
answers: Ans. Saccharides.

questions: Q. 7. What are glycans?
answers: Ans. Glycans are polysaccharides, they are made up of sugars.

questions: Q. 8. How many polypeptide chains are present in an multimeric protein?
answers: Ans. A protein having two or more polypeptides is called multimeric proteins.

questions: Q. 9. Why starch turns blue black with iodine?
answers: Ans. Appearance of blue colour with the addition of iodine is due to its reaction with amylose fraction of starch.

questions: Q. 10. Name the sugar found in fruits.
answers: Ans. Fructose.

questions: Q. 11. What are lipids?
answers: Ans. Lipids are the esters of fatty acids.

questions: Q. 12. What are micro-nutrients?
answers: Ans. Iron in ferritin.

questions: Q. 20. What is the role of myoglobin?
answers: Ans. Myoglobin attaches to one atom of oxygen.

questions: Q. 21. What is peptidoglycan?
answers: Ans. Peptidoglycan are composed of polysaccharide chains cross - linked by short peptides. These are found in cell wall of bacteria and blue-green algae.

questions: Q. 22. Name one fibrous and one globular protein.
answers: Ans. Myosin and actin are fibrous proteins. Egg albumin and glutelins are globular proteins.

questions: Q. 23. Lipids are not biomacromolecules. Why?
answers: Ans. Because their molecular weight does not exceed 800 Da and they are very small molecular mass compounds.

questions: Q. 24. Who proposed secondary structure of DNA?
answers: Ans. Watson and Crick.

questions: Q. 25. What are amphipathic lipids?
answers: Ans. Lipid molecules which possess both hydrophilic and hydrophobic properties are called amphipathic lipids.

questions: Q. 26. Name the polymer which make the exoskeleton of insects.
answers: Ans. Chitin a polymer of glucosamine forms the exoskeleton of insects.

questions: Q. 27. What is the name given to the inactive form of trypsin?
answers: Ans. Trypsinogen.

questions: Q. 28. Name a protein which act as a carrier.
answers: Ans. Haemoglobin.

questions: Q. 29. Name the enzyme present in the saliva.
answers: Ans. Salivary amylase or ptyalin.

questions: Q. 30. What do you understand by amphoteric nature of proteins?
answers: Ans. A chemical, like protein, carrying both positive and negative charge is called amphoteric.

questions: Q. 31. Define isoelectric point.
answers: Ans. Isoelectric point of the amino acid is defined as the point at which a molecule exist as zwitter ion with no net charge.

questions: Q. 32. Which macromolecules in the cells have phosphodiester bonds? 13]  [KVS 2012-
answers: Ans. Nucleic acids (DNA and RNA).

questions: Q. 33. What do you mean by PUFA?
answers: Ans. Poly Unsaturated Fatty Acid.

questions: Q. 34. What is activation energy?
answers: Ans. Activation energy is the initial input of the energy required to initiate a reaction.

questions: Q. 35. What is zymogen?
answers: Ans. The inactive state of enzyme is called zymogen or proenzyme.

questions: Q. 36. What are ligases?
answers: Ans. Ligases are the enzymes that join two substrate molecules.

questions: Q. 37. Define allosteric modulation or feedback inhibition.
answers: Ans. It is an irreversible inhibition of enzyme activity by the presence of a substance that has no structural similarity with the substrate.

questions: Q. 38. Who coined the term enzyme?
answers: Ans. Kuhne coined the term enzyme.

questions: Q. 39. What is an active site?
answers: Ans. The part of enzyme that take part in catalyzing biochemical reaction is called active site.

questions: Q. 40. In which case a cofactor becomes a prosthetic group?
answers: Ans. A cofactor that firmly attaches to the apoenzyme is called prosthetic group.

questions: Q. 41. Define isozymes.
answers: Ans. The multiple molecular forms of an enzyme occurring in the same organism and having a similar substrate activity are called isozymes.

questions: Q. 42. What is a holoenzyme?
answers: Ans. The complete conjugate enzyme, consisting of an apoenzyme and a cofactor, is called holoenzyme.

questions: Q. 43. What are hydrolases?
answers: Ans. Hydrolases break up large molecules into smaller ones with the help of hydrogen and hydroxyl groups of water molecules.

questions: Q. 44. What is inhibitor?
answers: Ans. A substance which binds to enzyme and does not allow substrate to bind with the enzyme. This reduces the activity of the enzyme.

questions: Q. 45. What is turn over number?
answers: Ans. The number of substrate molecules changed per minute by a molecule of enzyme is called turn over number.
